properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintery mix is expected for Thursday into Friday. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 60 km/h. Locations: central to eastern Nova Scotia. Time span: Thursday afternoon until Friday afternoon. Remarks: Precipitation is expected to begin as snow Thursday afternoon then transition to a mix of ice pellets or freezing rain in the evening and overnight. Freezing rain may persist over Cape Breton into Friday morning before a changeover to rain showers or flurries. Precipitation will taper off Friday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-25T23:31:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-25T07:32:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0298436211.2020
Area: Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong winds gusting to 70 km/h and fresh snow are reducing visibility in the region. Conditions are expected to improve early this morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-25T17:59:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-25T10:19:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2001388086.2020
Area: Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected tonight into Wednesday. Snow will begin early this evening and will be accompanied by strong northeasterly winds of 50 gusting to 70 km/h producing whiteouts at times. The snow will taper off early Wednesday morning but the strong winds will continue and may generate blowing snow through the morning hours. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-25T18:24:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-25T02:55:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3778083905.2020
Area: Fort Severn
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 70 km/h except 90 along parts of the coast. Locations: Clarenville, Terra Nova, and Bonavista Peninsula. Time span: continuing until late this afternoon. Remarks: Snow and strengthening northerly winds will combine to cause poor visibilities in blowing snow for much of today. Conditions are expected to improve late this afternoon. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-25T22:52:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-25T06:53:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0934141570.2020
Area: Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm tonight. Snow, heavy at times, is expected tonight before tapering off to light snow Wednesday morning. Total snowfall accumulations with this winter storm are expected to be near 25 cm by Wednesday morning. Brisk north or northeast winds gusting to 50 or 60 km/h will also produce blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-25T15:19:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-25T02:54:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3571514693.2020
Area: Sachigo Lake - Bearskin Lake, Big Trout Lake - Kasabonika, Sandy Lake - Weagamow Lake - Deer Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: near 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 80 km/h. Locations: Terra Nova and Bonavista Peninsula. Time span: continuing until late Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will continue tonight. Snowfall rates will begin to ease by morning on Wednesday, but strengthening northerly winds will persist through much of the day resulting in blowing snow and poor visibilities. Conditions are expected to improve late in the day on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-25T17:34:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-25T01:35:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1772269369.2020
Area: Bonavista Peninsula, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm ending today. Snow, heavy at times, will taper off this afternoon. Total snowfall accumulations near 25 cm are likely by this afternoon. Brisk north or northeast winds gusting to 50 or 60 km/h will also produce blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 70 km/h. Locations: Burin Peninsula and Connaigre Peninsula. Time span: continuing until Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, and blowing snow will persist tonight. The snow will taper off during the morning on Wednesday, and blowing snow will ease as temperatures rise. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-25T16:59:49-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Additional snowfall: near 2 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 70 km/h. Locations: Burin and Connaigre Peninsulas. Time span: ending this morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to redevelop this morning and persist for a couple of hours before ending. Strong winds accompanying the snow will cause poor visibilities in blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-25T16:30:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-25T07:42:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3499239966.2020
